Science Title: Scientists have found a way to make the eye shine like a laser – even when not using light 
 Text: Usually I don't post stuff about scientific findings, but this is an amazing, simple, and effective method that allows you to use just one photon instead of multiple ones. Basically it uses extremely short wavelengths of light, which are much more powerful than visible light. This means you can focus on something close so as to separate two very different images; in other words, you could switch images if you couldn't see your fingertips from across the room. Science Title: A new study has found that the lunar dust is actually in a much lower concentration than previously thought. 
 Text: We know from science experiments on the moon how water and organic compounds can settle out of space dust; but it turns out this stuff doesn't always stay there. It often becomes incredibly dense after traveling through the atmosphere for negligible distances and accumulates at high altitudes. This was discovered by NASA with an experiment they performed back in 2009. The researchers measured both atmospheric pressure as well as density to see if there were any differences. They identified 10 areas between 10 km up where their data showed similar amounts of carbon dioxide in different altitudes around Earth. But when you get down below about 1 km, things start getting interesting again. First, it turned out that not all parts of our planet are being

Science Title: A newly identified gene in the human genome may determine whether people are more biologically related to their babies than previously thought. 
 Text: [Helmholtz](en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholz) is named after German physicist Hermann von Helmholtz (1862-1930). He was considered an expert on electrical and magnetic phenomena, including how sound propagates through matter. His work led him to his discovery of the frequency of a certain electric field that can be used as a measure for physical distance. The eye detects light by detecting different frequencies of this field, which we call visible light. Scientists have known since the 19th century that, when a part or object moves near another part, its relative distance increases with time.
